OOC: This is a explaination. You don't have to read it unless you 
want to be bored. =P (or interested, if you like physics and stuff.)

The boulder would land first, but not because it weighs more, 
because the feather float, it catches air. If it couldn't catch air, and 
therefore couldn't float, then they would both land at the same time. 
Ever watch Bill Nye: Science Guy? Wait.... lemme think about 
this.  Weight is mass multiplied by gravity, therefore force. Force 
doesn't affect velocity. 
	The equation you would have needed to use to calculate how 
fast the objects are traveling is Ep + Ek = Ep + Ek (Ek=kinetic 
energy, and Ep=potential energy). 
	Ek on the left side would cancel, because v=0 (v=velocity). The 
Ep on the right side would also cancel out, since h=0 (h=height). 	
	That leaves Ep=Ek. Ep=mgh, and Ek=0.5mv^2. (the " ^ " sign 
represents "to the power of"). 
	Then you'd have mgh=0.5mv^2. Mass cancels, making leaving 
us with gh=0.5v^2. 
Thus, I conclude that mass doesn't affect how fast you fall, only 
how high you are at the start.

PS: weight is a force, in newtons. Mass is usually in kilograms, or 
pounds etc.



On 5 Apr 2001, at 15:42, dcoburn wrote:

> OOC: Hehe, rAuq, weight does effect how fast you fall.  If you took a feather, and a boulder, and dropped them from the same height, which would land first?  The boulder, because it WEIGHS more.
